objectives.description: Recognize the financial and social implications of gambling at both individual and community levels.
View gambling as entertainment with an expected cost rather than as a source of financial gain.
Understand the concepts of problem and pathological gambling and their effects on personal and community well-being.
Create strategies for responsible gambling practices that minimize potential harms while allowing enjoyment.

terms.definition: Viewing gambling as a leisure activity with an expected cost, like movies or concerts, not a way to make money.
terms.example: Setting aside $50 from your entertainment budget for a casino visit, expecting to lose it for the experience

terms.definition: Gambling behavior that disrupts personal, family, or vocational pursuits with increasing preoccupation and frequency.
terms.example: Chasing losses, lying about gambling, borrowing money to gamble, neglecting responsibilities

terms.definition: A tax that takes a larger percentage of income from low-income earners than high-income earners.
terms.example: Gambling revenue often comes disproportionately from lower-income households, functioning like a regressive tax

terms.definition: Practices designed to prevent gambling-related harms: setting limits, using only disposable income, accepting losses.
terms.example: Budget limits, time limits, never chasing losses, not borrowing to gamble, knowing when to stop

leftPanel.title: The Entertainment Mindset
paragraphs: When approached responsibly, gambling is a form of entertainment—not a way to make money.
Like movies, concerts, or dining out, gambling has an associated cost that should come from your entertainment budget.
The key difference: other entertainment guarantees 100% loss of money spent, while gambling offers variable outcomes—but still with an expected loss over time.

highlightBox.text: � The "cost" of gambling = the money you're willing to lose for the experience. Any winnings are a bonus, not an expectation.

infoCard.title: Gambling Budget Questions:

leftPanel.title: Potential Benefits
paragraphs: Entertainment & Recreation: Excitement, socialization, break from routine
Cognitive Stimulation: Strategy games like poker involve skill development
Social Interaction: Casinos, bingo halls provide community connections
Occasional Winnings: Though not expected, wins can be enjoyable

layoutData.title: Understanding the Progression
paragraphs: Gambling behavior exists on a spectrum. Recognizing where you are helps identify warning signs before problems develop.

keyPoint.text: ⚠️ Small changes in behavior can gradually lead to significant problems. Awareness and early intervention are crucial.

leftPanel.title: Economic Benefits
paragraphs: Tax Revenue: Funds public services, education, infrastructure
Job Creation: Casinos and related businesses employ thousands
Tourism: Gambling destinations attract visitors who spend broadly
Economic Development: Construction and ongoing operations revitalize areas

scenario.name: David: Responsible Gambling Approach in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: David enjoys visiting a casino about once every two months. Before each visit, he sets aside $100 from his entertainment budget—about 5% of his discretionary income after all bills and savings are paid.
He views this money as the cost of entertainment. He sets a 3-hour timer on his phone. Whether winning or losing, he leaves when the timer goes off or when he loses his $100—whichever comes first.
David considers his casino visits similar to a concert or special dinner—entertainment with a known cost, and any winnings are a bonus.

outcomes.detail: Leaves when timer goes off in {{STATE_NAME}}

scenario.name: Mark: Progression to Problem Gambling in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Mark began gambling occasionally with a $200 monthly budget. After a few big wins, he started going more frequently, convinced he had developed a "system."
When significant losses occurred, Mark began drawing from his savings to "win back" what he'd lost. He started using credit cards when savings ran low.
He found himself thinking about gambling at work, canceling social plans to gamble, and lying to friends and family about where his money was going.

takeaways.title: Community Tradeoffs
